title: Stock brokerages fear hit from bank tax
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Oct 3, 2015, 20:21 BST - UK Markets closed Stock brokerages fear hit from bank tax By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 21 minutes ago 16.05 +1.04 
George Osborne’s bank tax could hit firms well beyond the traditional definition of the banking sector, including small securities brokerages 
Brokerages across the financial services sector could be hit by the bank tax, The Telegraph understands, rather than just the traditional banks that are the official target of the Chancellor’s latest charge. 
Securities brokers including Cenkos, Numis and Canaccord Genuity (Other OTC: CCORF - news ) are understood to be making overtures to the Treasury in an effort to persuade officials to remove the tax from the sector or to reduce its impact. 
They join the challenger banks and building societies which have already launched public lobbying campaigns against the tax. 
They argue they are being unfairly hit as they were not responsible for causing the financial crisis, and the government had previously said it wanted to encourage the alternative lenders to grow and to compete with the giant banks. 
Now (NYSE: DNOW - news ) it appears the tax goes well beyond those lenders. Despite its name, the bank tax will apply to investment managers and brokerages, which are not traditionally seen as banks. 
The tax is due to come into force next year, and was introduced by George Osborne in his July Budget. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) charges banks an extra 8pc corporation tax on profits of above £25m . The tax was introduced in part in exchange for a reduction in the bank levy a tax on the balance sheets of Britain’s biggest banks, who had complained it made their international operations less competitive. 
Small cap brokerages typically have profits which are close to the £25m threshold or even below it, but the sector has seen substantial growth in recent years, picking up more corporate broking mandates and taking roles on capital markets deals. 
As a result, they fear that growth could be impeded by an extra tax. 
Overall, the Office for Budget Responsibility expects the tax changes will raise £1.6bn over five years. However, estimates from analysts at EY believe it could bring in as much as £8bn for the Treasury. 
A group of challenger banks led by Paul Lynam, the chief executive of Secure Trust Bank who also head the British Bankers’ Association’s challenger bank panel, did go to meet Treasury officials last month. Other banks involved include Metro Bank, Aldermore, TSB and Close Brothers (LSE: CBG.L - news ) . 
However, they failed to win any immediate concessions from the Chancellor’s office. 
Several of the banks want to raise the threshold on the tax to profits of £250m per year, a level which would also benefit the brokerages which face paying the charge as things stand. 
In a letter to the banks ahead of last month’s meeting, top official Charles Roxburgh indicated that before the tax can be cut back, the complainants need to be able to put forward workable alternative plans for raising the funds. 
The Treasury declined to comment on its interactions with individual businesses on tax matters (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
